title: Thousands stuck in stadium ‘hell’
text:
What are these? Thousands were packed into a stadium in 45 degree heat waiting to be registered. Picture: ANGELOS TZORTZINIS Source: AFP 
AN idyllic Greek island has been transformed into “hell” for refugees that is tantamount to “state abuse” according to the head of a major medical agency. 
Medicines Sans Fronteirs director of Operations Brice de la Vigne said “it’s like hell” on Kos where temperatures have reached 45C and up to 2000 refugees including women, babies and small children were locked in a football stadium without access to food, water or bathroom facilities this week. 
“What was previously a situation of state inaction is now one of state abuse, with police using increasingly heavy-handed force against these vulnerable people.” 
He said the agency called for Greek authorities to organise facilities for people arriving on shore eight months ago and is “appalled” they have failed to do so. 
“A site big enough to welcome all with minimum standards has yet to be designated. One is left to wonder what more the Greek authorities need to rise up to the occasion, take their responsibilities, and receive these people humanely and with dignity,” he said. Authorities forced people into an abandoned football stadium without drinking water or food this week. Picture: Alexander Zemlianichenko. Source: AP Fire extinguishers and extra riot police have been used to control the crowds. Picture: ANGELOS TZORTZINIS Source: AFP 
More than 7000 people have arrived in Greece in July, many of them from Syria fleeing the Islamic State. It’s double the number that arrived in the previous month and authorities have been struggling to cope, with people forced to live in filthy conditions or sleep in parks around the city. 
This week, Greek police have tried to move people from urban areas towards a stadium on the edge of town where they can give their names to police to be registered. 
Overnight police officers worked to register more than 1000 people inside the stadium, however many were still outside waiting. 
Kos Mayor Giorgos Kyritsis said the extra manpower means the process is operating more smoothly now. However with Greece taking over from Italy as the main entry point to Europe, it shows no sign of abating. 
Riot police have been sent to the area and Minister of State Alekos Flabouraris said a 2500 person cruise ship has also been dispatched to act as a processing centre. 
Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has called for European Union help with the crisis, as Greece struggles to deal with major economic woes. Many sleep outside while waiting for registration. Picture: AP Photo/Yorgos Karahalis. Source: AP A boy smiles after reaching Greece from Turkey. Picture: AP Photo/Yorgos Karahalis. Source: AP 7000 people have arrived on the island since July, which has around 30,000 locals. Picture: ANGELOS TZORTZINIS Source: AFP Many are Syrian migrants and refugees fleeing from the Islamic State. Picture: AP Photo/Alexander Zemlianichenko. Source: AP
